The purpose of these pages is to offer general guidance regarding current copyright issues and the information provided aims to empower you to make informed choices when using copyright materials in your teaching and research. The University of Central Lancashire aims to ensure that all copying for its teaching and research activities complies with current copyright law however, the information provided here should not be taken as legal advice. If you are in any doubt at all about whether you can use particular material, please seek further advice from a copyright advisor by emailing copyright@uclan.ac.uk
Welcome to the copyright for staff help guide

This resource was developed by the University of Manchester Library’s Copyright Guidance Service. The information provided within this resource is intended as general guidance only, and an interpretation of current copyright issues and practice at the University of Manchester. Whilst every effort is made to ensure that this resource is up to date and accurate, the University of Manchester does not warrant, nor does it accept any responsibility or liability for, the accuracy or completeness of the content or for any loss which may arise from reliance on information contained in it. It is not a definitive guide and should not be construed as legal advice. This resource is available for reuse under a CC-BY-NC licence. For full licence terms, visit the Creative Commons website. Is it in the public domain?
Public domain works are no longer subject to copyright restrictions, so you are free to use the material however you like!
Is it in the public domain?

Public domain works are those whose intellectual property rights have expired, been forfeited, or are otherwise inapplicable. For example, creative work where the author died more than 70 years ago. When trying to determine whether something is in the public domain or not, consider the following: 1) the rules of your own country apply (UK copyright law) 2) a reproduction of a work has a new copyright life, e.g. a digital image of an old photograph 3) any adaptation of a work is a new copyright work
If you still aren’t sure contact us for further help and advice email:
Is it open access or Creative Commons licensed?

Creative Commons materials have been specifically licensed to enable people to reuse them. You are free to use these materials, as long as you adhere to the terms of the licence that the material has been released under.

There are a number of different Creative Commons (CC) licences, which allow various levels of permission. The basic, most open licence is CC-0, which allows anyone to re-use and adapt materials for any purpose, with no need to attribute the original author. A number of letter designations can be added to impose further restrictions, such as NC (non-commercial) and ND (no derivatives). These can be combined to meet specific requirements. You are free to use CC licensed material as long as you adhere to the terms of the type of licence that the material has been released under. You can use the Creative Commons search page to find CC licensed content.

Our Copyright Licensing Agency (CLA) licence covers the photocopying and scanning of most UK publications and some US and international publishers. It allows: Multiple photocopies of limited extracts from copyright protected printed books, journals and magazines. Digital copies of limited extracts from copyright protected printed books, journals and magazines. Details of excluded UK and US publishers, and included overseas countries, can be found on the CLA’s website.

Creative Commons is a non-profit organisation that provides licensing information aimed at achieving a mutual sharing and flexible approach to copyright. Their easy-to-use copyright licences provide a simple, standardised way to give the public permission to share and use creative work. You are free to use CC licensed material as long as you adhere to the terms of the type of licence that the materials has been released under. You can use the Creative Commons search page to find CC licensed content.

The ERA (Educational Recording Agency) provides licence schemes to member HE institutions to cover the use of recorded broadcast media in teaching and learning. The ERA+ Licence grants the right to record broadcasts for non-commercial educational purposes by making ERA Recordings. UCLan currently has an ERA+ Licence. This also allows licenced ERA recordings to be accessed by students and teachers online from outside the premises of the their establishment.

In certain circumstances, some works may be copied under a copyright exception where the use is considered to be “fair dealing”. Fair dealing is not defined in law, and the fairness of a particular use will be judged according to its own circumstances. However, there are a number of factors you can take into account when assessing fairness, including: The amount copied - do not copy excessive amounts of a work, and be aware that in some cases the type of work may be a factor The purpose of copying - if the purpose is for teaching a limited number of students, this may be considered fair

Researchers and students are allowed to copy limited extracts of works for non-commercial research and private study. This includes text, images, sound and video recordings. The amount is limited by fair dealing and must be sufficiently acknowledged/attributed.
